newsitem.title: CHINA: Huge imports send China steel prices plunging.
newsitem.headline: Huge imports send China steel prices plunging.

text.p: Massive steel imports this year sent Chinese prices plunging in August and caused a glut, the Trade Information on Chinese Materials and Equipment said.

Steel imports in the first seven months were 9.14 million tonnes, up 24.2 percent from the same period in 1995, the trade magazine said in a report available on Monday. If imports continue at that level, China will import 15.6 million tonnes in 1996 -- far above the official target of 10 million, it said.
Continued high imports depressed prices for 10 of 12 types of steel materials in August, with prices of some materials falling by as much as 4.43 percent during the month, it said.
Chinese steel output in the first seven months was 48.78 million tonnes, an increase of 2.42 million tonnes or 5.22 percent, compared with the year-ago period, it said.
China is expected to produce nearly 100 million tonnes of steel this year, up from 93.5 million in 1995.
Sluggish steel demand was partly due to state controls on fixed investment and cash shortages in factories, it said.

Steel exports in the first seven months slumped 37.5 percent year-on-year to 2.17 million tonnes, the trade magazine said. At that level 1996 exports would total less than 4.0 million tonnes, versus 5.93 million tonnes in 1995.
